Name: Add audio breakpoint
Description: Can I add audio breakpoint whenever a line of code is executed?

Safari.Notes:
1. In **Sources** > Add a breakpoint by clicking the line number > Right click and select "Edit Breakpoint...".
2. Click **Add Action** > Select "Play Sound" to hear a beep sound each time the statement is executed.

Name: Add class to element
Description: Can I add a class to an HTML element?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Look for ".cls" button in the Styles pane next to the Filter field.
2. Click the button and search for the existing class names to add to the element.

Firefox.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Look for ".cls" button in the styles section next to the Filter Styles field.
2. Click the button and search for the existing class names to add to the element.

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Look for ".cls" button in the Styles pane next to the Filter field.
2. Click the button and search for the existing class names to add to the element.
Edge.References: 1. "Add class to an element" - Edge DevTools [documentation](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/devtools-guide-chromium/css/reference#add-a-class-to-an-element)

Safari.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Look for "Classes" button in bottom row of the styles section next to the Filter field.
2. Click the button and search for the existing class names to add to the element.

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Look for ".cls" button in the Styles pane next to the Filter field.
2. Click the button and search for the existing class names to add to the element.

Polypane.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Open the "attributes" tab 
2. Add a new class into the class field, known classes from the page and CSS will automatically be suggested.
3. If there is no class attribute yet, add it as a new attribute and known classes will also be automatically suggested.

Name: Add conditional breakpoint
Description: Can I set a conditional breakpoint while debugging code?

Chrome.Notes:
1. In **Sources**, right click the line number and select "Add a conditional breakpoint..."
2. Input the conditional expression on which the execution should pause, and press `Enter`.

Firefox.Notes:
1. In **Debugger**, right click the line number and select "Add condition"
2. Input the conditional expression on which the execution should pause, and press `Enter`.

Edge.Notes:
1. In **Sources**, right click the line number and select "Add a conditional breakpoint..."
2. Input the conditional expression on which the execution should pause, and press `Enter`.

Safari.Notes:
1. In **Sources**, click the line number to **Add Breakpoint** > Right click on the line number and select "Edit Breakpoint...".
2. Input the conditional expression on which the execution should pause, and press `Enter`.

Opera.Notes:
1. In **Sources**, right click the line number and select "Add a conditional breakpoint..."
2. Input the conditional expression on which the execution should pause, and press `Enter`.

Name: Add custom device
Description: Can I add a custom device for a responsive design mode?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open **Settings** (`F1` or `Shift+?`) > Devices > Click "Add custom device...". 
2. Enter the "Device Name" and other details associated with the device. Click the "Add" button.

Firefox.Notes:
1. Open **Responsive** **Design** **Mode** (`Cmd+Opt+M` or `Ctrl+Shift+M`) > Select "Edit List..." from the list of devices.
2. In **Device** **Settings**, click "Add Custom Device..." > Enter the **Name** and other related details > Click "Save".

Edge.Notes:
1. Open **Settings** (`F1` or `Shift+?`) > Devices > Click "Add custom device...". 
2. Enter the "Device Name" and other details associated with the device. Click the "Add" button.

Opera.Notes:
1. Open **Settings** (`F1` or `Shift+?`) > Devices > Click "Add custom device...". 
2. Enter the "Device Name" and other details associated with the device. Click the "Add" button.

Polypane.Notes:
1. Click the "+" button in the workspace, double-click anywhere in the free space, or press `Ctrl/Cmd+N`  
2. Once the new device is added you can resize it manually and set the device and emulation options with the Emulation settings.

Name: Add custom headers to Network table
Description: Can I add custom header columns to the Network requests table?

Notes: 1. In the **Network** panel, right click on the column headers > Response Headers > Manage Header Columns.
2. In the **Manage Header Columns** popup window, click "Add Custom Header". Enter the custom header name, and click **Add** to add a new column to the Network requests table.
1. In the **Network** panel, right click on the column headers > Response Headers > Manage Header Columns.
2. In the **Manage Header Columns** popup window, click "Add Custom Header". Enter the custom header name, and click **Add** to add a new column to the Network requests table.
1. In the **Network** panel, right click on the column headers > Response Headers > Manage Header Columns.
2. In the **Manage Header Columns** popup window, click "Add Custom Header". Enter the custom header name, and click **Add** to add a new column to the Network requests table.

Name: Add inline styles
Description: Can I add inline styles to an HTML element?

Chrome.Notes: 1. Inspect element > In the **Styles** pane, click "element.style" to input the inline style.

Firefox.Notes: 1. Inspect element > In the **Rules** pane, click "element​" to input the inline style.

Edge.Notes: 1. Inspect element > In the **Styles** pane, click "element.style" to input the inline style.
Edge.References: 1. "Add a CSS declaration to an element", by Edge DevTools [documentation](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/devtools-guide-chromium/css/#add-a-css-declaration-to-an-element)

Safari.Notes: 1. Inspect element > In the **Styles** pane, click inside "Style Attribute​" braces to input the inline style.

Opera.Notes: 1. Inspect element > In the **Styles** pane, click "element.style" to input the inline style.

Polypane.Notes: 1. Inspect element > In the **Styles** pane, click "property" under "element.style" to input the inline style.

Name: Add logpoint
Description: Can I add log points to source code for debugging?

Chrome.Notes: 1. In **Sources** > Right click on the line number and select "Add logpoint..." > Input the log statement to print in the **Console** without actually writing `console.log` statements.

Firefox.Notes: 1. In **Debugger** > Right click on the line number and select "Add log" > Input the log statement to print in the **Console** without actually writing `console.log` statements.

Edge.Notes: 1. In **Sources** > Right click on the line number and select "Add logpoint..." > Input the log statement to print in the **Console** without actually writing `console.log` statements.

Opera.Notes: 1. In **Sources** > Right click on the line number and select "Add logpoint..." > Input the log statement to print in the **Console** without actually writing `console.log` statements.

Name: Autocomplete styles using values
Description: Can I autocomplete style declaration just using values?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect an element > Navigate to the styles section (next to the DOM tree).
2. Add new styles by directly entering the values like "bold", "italic" etc., and the devtools will automatically suggest the corresponding `<property>: <value>` pair for the given input.

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect an element > Navigate to the styles section (next to the DOM tree).
2. Add new styles by directly entering the values like "bold", "italic" etc., and the devtools will automatically suggest the corresponding `<property>: <value>` pair for the given input.

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect an element > Navigate to the styles section (next to the DOM tree).
2. Add new styles by directly entering the values like "bold", "italic" etc., and the devtools will automatically suggest the corresponding `<property>: <value>` pair for the given input.

Polypane.Notes:
1. Inspect an element > Navigate to the styles tab 
2. Click the "propety" field under the style you want to edit, and the devtools will automatically suggest appropriate style properties and values for the current element.

Name: Block request URL
Description: Can I block a network request?

Chrome.References: 1. "What's new in DevTools 59", on Chrome Developers [Blog](https://developer.chrome.com/blog/new-in-devtools-59/#block-requests)
Chrome.Notes: 1. In the **Network** tab, right click on the request and select "Block request URL". This will open the "Network request blocking" drawer that will let you manage all your blocked requests.

Firefox.Notes: 1. In the **Network** tab, right click on the request and select "Block URL". This will open the "Blocking" pane in the left sidebar to manage all the blocking requests.

Edge.Notes: 1. In the **Network** tab, right click on the request and select "Block request URL". This will open the "Network request blocking" drawer that will let you manage all your blocked requests.
Edge.References: 1. "Block a network request by using the Network tool", on Edge DevTools [documentation](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/devtools-guide-chromium/network-request-blocking/network-request-blocking-tool#block-a-network-request-by-using-the-network-tool)

Safari.Notes:
1. In the **Network** tab, right click on the request **Name**, and select "Block Request URL".
2. In the **Sources** tab, under the **Local Overrides** section in the left sidebar, you can manage the blocked request.

Opera.Notes: 1. In the **Network** tab, right click on the request and select "Block request URL". This will open the "Network request blocking" drawer that will let you manage all your blocked requests.

Name: Block request domain
Description: Can I block all network requests of a domain?

Chrome.Notes: 1. In the **Network** panel, right click on the network request, and select "Block request domain". This will open the **Network request blocking** drawer that will let you manage blocked network requests.

Firefox.Notes:
1. In the **Network** panel, click the "Request Blocking" icon in the toolbar to open the **Blocking** pane in the left sidebar.
2. Add the domain name in the input box to block all the matching requests for that domain.

Edge.Notes: 1. In the **Network** panel, right click on the network request, and select "Block request domain". This will open the **Network** **request** **blocking** drawer that will let you manage blocked network requests.
Edge.References: 1. "Block a network request by using the Network tool", on Edge DevTools [documentation](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/devtools-guide-chromium/network-request-blocking/network-request-blocking-tool#block-a-network-request-by-using-the-network-tool)

Safari.Notes:
1. In the **Network** panel, right click on the request and select "Create Response Local Override" to open the **Sources** panel, which contains the list of all local overrides.
2. Right click on the override and select "Edit Local Override...". Add the domain name in the URL pattern and use Status as `404: Not Found` to block all the network requests for that domain.

Opera.Notes: 1. In the **Network** panel, right click on the network request, and select "Block request domain". This will open the **Network request blocking** drawer that will let you manage blocked network requests.

Name: Block request by URL pattern
Description: Can I block all network request matching a URL pattern?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open **Command** **Menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Run "Show Network request blocking". This will open the **Network request blocking** drawer.
2. Click the "+" button and add the URL pattern > Add. Reload the page for the changes to take effect. Filter on **Blocked Requests** by enabling the checkbox in the toolbar.

Firefox.Notes:
1. In the **Network** panel, click the **Request** **Blocking** icon in the toolbar, to open the **Blocking** pane in the left sidebar. 
2. Input the URL pattern and press `Enter`. Reload the page to see the changes take effect.

Edge.Notes:
1. Open **Command** **Menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Run "Show Network request blocking". This will open the **Network** **request** **blocking** drawer.
2. Click the "+" button and add the URL pattern > Add. Reload the page for the changes to take effect. Filter on **Blocked** **Requests** by enabling the checkbox in the toolbar.

Safari.Notes:
1. In the **Sources** panel, Add a new **Local** **Override** by clicking the "+" (Create Resource) button.
2. Select the **Type** as "Block", and enter the regex for the URL pattern to override the network request for. Reload the page to see the changes take effect.

Opera.Notes:
1. Open **Command** **Menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Run "Show Network request blocking". This will open the **Network** **request** **blocking** drawer.
2. Click the "+" button and add the URL pattern > Add. Reload the page for the changes to take effect. Filter on **Blocked** **Requests** by enabling the checkbox in the toolbar.

Name: Capture full page screenshot
Description: Can I take full page screenshot of a website?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open **Command Menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) & Run > "Capture full size screenshot" and press `Enter`.
2. This will save a PNG image with url as the filename in the **Downloads** directory.

Firefox.Notes:
1. In the **Inspector** panel, right click on the `html` node > select "Screenshot Node".
2. This will save a PNG image with current date time as the filename in the **Downloads** directory.

Edge.Notes:
1. Open **Command** **Menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) & Run > "Capture full size screenshot" and press `Enter`.
2. This will save a PNG image with url as the filename in the **Downloads** directory.

Safari.Notes:
1. In the **Elements** panel, right click on the `html` node and select "Capture Screenshot".
2. This will save a PNG image with current date time as the filename in the **Downloads** directory.

Opera.Notes:
1. Open **Command** **Menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) & Run > "Capture full size screenshot" and press `Enter`.
2. This will save a PNG image with url as the filename in the **Downloads** directory.

Polypane.Notes: 1. Click the "Camera" icon above the pane you want to screenshot and select "Full page". This will open the screenshot in the screenshot editor.

Name: Capture HD screenshot
Description: Can I capture high definition screenshot of a page?

Notes: 1. In **Console**, run the `:screenshot --dpr 2` command to take a high definiton screenshot with the device pixel ratio set to 2.

Name: Capture node screenshot
Description: Can I take screenshot of a DOM node?

Chrome.Notes:
1. In the **Elements** panel, right click on the node and select "Capture node screenshot".
2. It retains visible background colour of elements with no background colour applied.

Firefox.Notes:
1. In the **Inspector** panel, right click on the node, and select "Screenshot Node".
2. Firefox does not retain background transparency of the element in the screenshot.

Edge.Notes:
1. In the **Elements** panel, right click on the node and select "Capture node screenshot".
2. It retains visible background colour of elements with no background colour applied.

Safari.Notes:
1. In the **Elements** panel, right click on the node in the DOM tree and click on "Capture Screenshot". 
2. Safari preserves the transparency for the elements with no applied background colour.

Opera.Notes:
1. In the **Elements** panel, right click on the node and select "Capture node screenshot".
2. It retains visible background colour of elements with no background colour applied.

Polypane.Notes: 1. Click the "Camera" icon above the pane you want to screenshot and select "Element". 2. Click the element you want to screenshot. 3. Alternatively, click the "Camera" icon in the Element inspector to screenshot the selected DOM node.

Name: Capture node stacktrace
Description: Can I capture node creation stack trace?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Enable "Capture node creation stacks" in Settings (`F1`) > Experiments.
2. In the **Elements** panel > Select the node > Open the **Stack Trace** pane in the side panel to show the stack trace of the node creation.

Edge.Notes:
1. Enable "Capture node creation stacks" in Settings (`F1`) > Experiments.
2. In the **Elements** panel > Select the node > Open the **Stack** **Trace** pane in the side panel to show the stack trace of the node creation.

Opera.Notes:
1. Enable "Capture node creation stacks" in Settings (`F1`) > Experiments.
2. In the **Elements** panel > Select the node > Open the **Stack** **Trace** pane in the side panel to show the stack trace of the node creation.

Name: Capture screenshot via console
Description: Can I take screenshot of a web page from the console?

Firefox.Notes:
1. Firefox has a built-in helper function `:screenshot` to capture screenshot of the current page from the console. 
2. For example:
```
    :screenshot
    :screenshot --fullpage
    :screenshot --selector .css-selector
```

Safari.Notes:
1. In Safari, you can capture screenshot of the viewport from the **Console** using `console.screenshot()`. 
2. Alternatively, pass the target node to the function to capture screenshot of a specific node.

Name: Capture viewport screenshot
Description: Can I take a screenshot of the viewport?

Chrome.Notes: 1. Open **Command** **menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Run "Capture screenshot" > Press `Enter`. By default, the screenshot will be saved in the `Downloads` directory.

Firefox.Notes: 1. In **Console**, use the built-in helper function `:screenshot` to capture screenshot of the current page.

Edge.Notes: 1. Open **Command** **menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Run "Capture screenshot" > Press `Enter`. By default, the screenshot will be saved in the `Downloads` directory.

Safari.Notes: 1. In **Console**, use `console.screenshot()` to capture the screenshot of the viewport.

Opera.Notes: 1. Open **Command** **menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Run "Capture screenshot" > Press `Enter`. By default, the screenshot will be saved in the `Downloads` directory.

Polypane.Notes: 1. Click the "Camera" icon above the pane you want to screenshot and select "Viewport". This will open the screenshot in the screenshot editor.

Name: Change color format
Description: Can I change authored color format to other formats like hsl, hwb etc?

Chrome.Notes:
1. In the **Styles** pane, hold the `Shift` key and click on the color preview box to cycle through the various color formats like `hex`, `rgb`, `hsl`, and `hwb`.
2. Alternatively, you can change the color format in the [color picker](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/devtools/css/reference/#color-picker) using the up-down arrow keys.

Firefox.Notes:
1. In the **Rules** pane, hold the `Shift` key and click on any color preview to change the color format.
2. It is also available as an [optional default](https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/devtools-user/settings/index.html#inspector).

Edge.Notes:
1. In the **Styles** pane, hold the `Shift` key and click on the color preview box to cycle through the various color formats like `rgb`, `hsl`, and `hwb`.
2. Alternatively, you can change the color format in the [color picker](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/devtools/css/reference/#color-picker) using the up-down arrow keys.

Safari.Notes: 1. In the **Styles** pane, hold the `Shift` key and click on the color preview box to cycle through the various color formats like `hex`, `rgb`, and `colors.`

Opera.Notes:
1. In the **Styles** pane, hold the `Shift` key and click on the color preview box to cycle through the various color formats like `rgb`, `hsl`, and `hwb`.
2. Alternatively, you can change the color format in the [color picker](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/devtools/css/reference/#color-picker) using the up-down arrow keys.

Name: Change devtools language
Description: Can I change the language of developer tools?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open **Settings** (`F1` or `Shift+?`) > Preferences > Under **Languages**, select the language from the dropdown > Reload DevTools.
2. Alternatively, Run **Command** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Input the language > select the language labelled "Appearance" > Reload DevTools.

Edge.Notes:
1. Open **Settings** (`F1` or `Shift+?`) > Preferences > Under **Languages**, select the language from the dropdown > Reload DevTools.
2. Alternatively, Run **Command** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Input the language > select the language labelled "Appearance" > Reload DevTools.
Edge.References: 1. "Change DevTools language settings", by Microsoft Edge Developer [documentation](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/devtools-guide-chromium/customize/localization).

Opera.Notes:
1. Open **Settings** (`F1` or `Shift+?`) > Preferences > Under **Languages**, select the language from the dropdown > Reload DevTools.
2. Alternatively, Run **Command** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Input the language > select the language labelled "Appearance" > Reload DevTools.

Name: Clear command history
Description: Can I clear the command history of the console?

Chrome.Notes: In the **Console** tab, right click anywhere > select "Clear console history" to remove all the commands from its history.

Edge.Notes: In the **Console** tab, right click anywhere > select "Clear console history" to remove all the commands from its history.

Opera.Notes: In the **Console** tab, right click anywhere > select "Clear console history" to remove all the commands from its history.

Name: Clear console
Description: Can I clear the console?

Chrome.Notes:
Three ways to clear a console:
1. Press `Ctrl+L` (on Windows/Linux) or `Cmd+K` (on MacOS) to clear the console.
2. Click on the "Clear Console" icon in the toolbar on the top left side.
3. Use `console.clear()` on the command line.

Firefox.Notes:
Three ways to clear a console:
1. Press `Ctrl+L` (on Windows/Linux) or `Cmd+K` (on MacOS) to clear the console.
2. Click on the "Clear the Web Console output" icon in the toolbar on the top left side.
3. Use `console.clear()` on the command line.

Edge.Notes:
Three ways to clear a console:
1. Press `Ctrl+L` (on Windows/Linux) or `Cmd+K` (on MacOS) to clear the console.
2. Click on the "Clear Console" icon in the toolbar on the top left side.
3. Use `console.clear()` on the command line.

Safari.Notes:
Three ways to clear a console:
1. Press `Cmd+K` or `Ctrl+L` on the keyboard.
2. Click the Trash icon in the top-right of the console toolbar.
3. Use `console.clear()` on the command line.

Opera.Notes:
Three ways to clear a console:
1. Press `Ctrl+L` (on Windows/Linux) or `Cmd+K` (on MacOS) to clear the console.
2. Click on the "Clear Console" icon in the toolbar on the top left side.
3. Use `console.clear()` on the command line.

Polypane.Notes:
Three ways to clear a console:
1. Press `Cmd/Ctrl+Shift+K` to clear the console.
2. Click on the "Clear Console" icon in the toolbar on the top left side.
3. Use `console.clear()` on the command line.

Name: Clear network log
Description: Can I clear network log?

Notes: 1. In the **Network** panel, click the **Clear network log** (`Cmd+K` or `Ctrl+L`) button in the toolbar to clear all the network requests.

Name: Copy cURL request
Description: Can I copy a network request as cURL?

Chrome.Notes: In the **Network** tab, right click on the request, Copy > Copy as cURL will copy the request with cURL command to the clipboard.

Firefox.Notes: 1. In the **Network** tab, right click on the request, Copy > Copy as cURL will copy the request with cURL command to the clipboard.

Edge.Notes: In the **Network** tab, right click on the request, Copy > Copy as cURL will copy the request with cURL command to the clipboard.

Safari.Notes: In the **Network** tab, right click on the request, "Copy as cURL" will copy the request with cURL command to the clipboard.

Opera.Notes: In the **Network** tab, right click on the request, Copy > Copy as cURL will copy the request with cURL command to the clipboard.

Name: Copy as Fetch
Description: Can I copy the request as window.fetch()?

Notes: 1. In the **Network** panel, right click on the network request > Copy > Copy as fetch.

Name: Copy as PowerShell
Description: Can I copy the request as a powershell script?

Notes: 1. In the **Network** panel, right click on the network request > Copy > Copy as PowerShell.

Name: Copy as CSS selector
Description: Can I copy a node's path as a CSS selector?

Chrome.Notes: In the **Elements** tab, right click on the element in the DOM tree > Copy > Copy selector.

Firefox.Notes: 1. In the **Inspector** tab, right click on the element in the DOM tree > Copy > CSS Selector.

Edge.Notes: In the **Elements** tab, right click on the element in the DOM tree > Copy > Copy selector.

Safari.Notes: In the **Elements** tab, right click on the element in the DOM tree > Copy > Selector Path.

Opera.Notes: In the **Elements** tab, right click on the element in the DOM tree > Copy > Copy selector.

Polypane.Notes: In the **Elements** panel, click the "Copy" icon in the navigator, then select "Copy CSS Selector"

Name: Copy image as data URI
Description: Can I copy an image as a data URI?

Notes:
1. In the **Network** panel, click the image request to open a side panel containing the request details. 
2. Open the **Preview** tab to preview the image and right click on the image > Copy image as data URI

1. In the **Network** panel, click the image request to open a side panel containing the request details. 
2. Open the **Preview** tab to preview the image and right click on the image > Copy image as data URI

1. In the **Network** panel, click the image request to open a side panel containing the request details. 
2. Open the **Preview** tab to preview the image and right click on the image > Copy image as data URI

Name: Copy as JS expression
Description: Can I copy a node's path to be used as a JavaScript expression?

Chrome.References: [1] Copy JS path, by Chrome DevTools [Docs](https://developer.chrome.com/blog/new-in-devtools-72/#copy)
Chrome.Notes: 1. In the **Elements** tab, right click on the node in the DOM tree > Copy > Copy JS path. This will copy the query selector to the node that can be used in the JS code.

Edge.Notes: 1. In the **Elements** tab, right click on the node in the DOM tree > Copy > Copy JS path. This will copy the query selector to the node that can be used in the JS code.

Opera.Notes: 1. In the **Elements** tab, right click on the node in the DOM tree > Copy > Copy JS path. This will copy the query selector to the node that can be used in the JS code.

Name: Copy node as HTML
Description: Can I copy a node as HTML?

Notes: 1. In the **Elements** panel, right click on the node > Copy > Copy outerHTML.

Name: Copy node styles
Description: Can I copy the styles applied to an element?

Notes: 1. In the **Elements** panel, right click on the node > Copy > Copy styles.
1. In the **Elements** panel, go to the "Computed" tab and click the "Copy styles" button.

Name: Copy object
Description: Can I copy an object from console?

Chrome.Notes: `copy(object)` copies a string representation of the specified object to the clipboard.

Firefox.Notes: 1. `copy(object)` copies a string representation of the specified object to the clipboard.

Edge.Notes: `copy(object)` copies a string representation of the specified object to the clipboard.

Safari.Notes: `copy(object)` copies a string representation of the specified object to the clipboard.

Opera.Notes: `copy(object)` copies a string representation of the specified object to the clipboard.

Name: Copy response text
Description: Can I copy the response object as text?

Notes: 1. In the **Network** panel, right click on the network request > Copy > Copy response.

Name: Copy styles as JS
Description: Can I copy style declarations as JavaScript object?

Chrome.Notes: 1. Inspect element > In the **Styles** pane, right click on the style declaration and select "Copy declaration as JS" or "Copy all declarations as JS" to copy one or all styles.

Edge.Notes: 1. Inspect element > In the **Styles** pane, right click on the style declaration and select "Copy declaration as JS" or "Copy all declarations as JS" to copy one or all styles.
Edge.References: [1] "What's new in DevTools 93?", by Edge Devtools [Docs](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/devtools-guide-chromium/whats-new/2021/07/devtools#copy-a-declaration-in-the-styles-pane-for-css-in-js-libraries)

Opera.Notes: 1. Inspect element > In the **Styles** pane, right click on the style declaration and select "Copy declaration as JS" or "Copy all declarations as JS" to copy one or all styles.

Name: Debug attr change
Description: Can I set breakpoint and debug attr changes of a node?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect element > Right click on the node in the DOM tree.
2. Select "Break on" > "attribute modifications". Reload the page.

Firefox.Notes:
1. Inspect element > Right click on the node in the DOM tree.
2. Select "Break on..." > "Attribute Modification". Reload the page.

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect element > Right click on the node in the DOM tree > Select "Break on" > Select "attribute modifications". 
2. Reload the page.

Safari.Notes:
1. Inspect element > Right click on the DOM node > Select "Break on" > Select "Attribute Modified".
2. Reload the page.

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect element > Right click on the node in the DOM tree.
2. Select "Break on" > "attribute modifications". Reload the page.

Name: Debug Event Listeners
Description: Can I debug event listeners by setting a breakpoint on all or specific events?

Chrome.Notes:
1. In the **Sources** tab, expand the **Event Listeners Breakpoints** section to see the list of event categories.
2. Expand a category and enable the checkbox for the event that needs to be debugged.

Firefox.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Debugger > Find and expand the Event Listener Breakpoints section in the right hand column.
2. To break when event listeners are hit, check the boxes next the events you are interested in. All of the standard events supported in your version of Firefox are listed, arranged by which API or API area they’re part of.
Firefox.References:
1. "Set event listener breakpoints" by [Firefox](https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/devtools-user/debugger/set_event_listener_breakpoints/index.html).
2. "Examine Event Listeners" by [Firefox](https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/devtools-user/page_inspector/how_to/examine_event_listeners/index.html#examine-event-listeners).
3. "Issue #5" by [@nclm](https://github.com/pankajparashar/canidev.tools/issues/5).

Edge.Notes:
1. In the **Sources** tab, expand the **Event** **Listeners** **Breakpoints** section to see the list of event categories.
2. Expand a category and enable the checkbox for the event that needs to be debugged.

Safari.Notes:
1. In the **Sources** tab, click the "+" button from the left sidebar in the **Breakpoints** section > Select "Events Breakpoint".
2. Enter the name of the event in the popup form to apply a breakpoint for a specific event.
3. Alternatively, you can set breakpoint on all the events by selecting "All Events" after clicking the "+" button.

Opera.Notes:
1. In the **Sources** tab, expand the **Event** **Listeners** **Breakpoints** section to see the list of event categories.
2. Expand a category and enable the checkbox for the event that needs to be debugged.

Name: Debug JavaScript
Description: Can I debug JavaScript using devtools?

Chrome.Notes:
1. In the **Sources** tab, open the `.js` file from the **Page** panel in the left sidebar. Set a breakpoint by clicking on the line number.
2. Perform the action necessary to trigger that line of code, which will pause the execution at the breakpoint.
3. Use the toolbar on the right sidebar to step-in/step-out, watch expressions, local vars while debugging through the code.
4. Alternatively, you can also add the `debugger;` statement in the code to pause execution of the code at that line.

Firefox.Notes:
1. In the **Debugger** tab, open the `.js` file from the **Sources** panel in the left sidebar. Set a breakpoint by clicking on the line number.
2. Perform the action necessary to trigger that line of code, which will pause the execution at the breakpoint.
3. Use the toolbar on the right sidebar to step-in/step-out, watch expressions, local vars while debugging through the code.
4. Alternatively, you can also add the `debugger;` statement in the code to pause execution of the code at that line.

Edge.Notes:
1. In the **Sources** tab, open the `.js` file from the **Page** panel in the left sidebar. Set a breakpoint by clicking on the line number.
2. Perform the action necessary to trigger that line of code, which will pause the execution at the breakpoint.
3. Use the toolbar on the right sidebar to step-in/step-out, watch expressions, local vars while debugging through the code.
4. Alternatively, you can also add the `debugger;` statement in the code to pause execution of the code at that line.

Safari.Notes:
1. In the **Sources** tab, open the `.js` file from the the left sidebar. Set a breakpoint by clicking on the line number.
2. Perform the action necessary to trigger that line of code, which will pause the execution at the breakpoint.
3. Once activated, use the toolbar on the left sidebar (top) to step-in/step-out, watch expressions, local vars while debugging through the code.
4. Alternatively, you can also add the `debugger;` statement in the code to pause execution of the code at that line.

Opera.Notes:
1. In the **Sources** tab, open the `.js` file from the **Page** panel in the left sidebar. Set a breakpoint by clicking on the line number.
2. Perform the action necessary to trigger that line of code, which will pause the execution at the breakpoint.
3. Use the toolbar on the right sidebar to step-in/step-out, watch expressions, local vars while debugging through the code.
4. Alternatively, you can also add the `debugger;` statement in the code to pause execution of the code at that line.

Name: Debug node removal
Description: Can I debug by setting a breakpoint when the node is removed from the DOM?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect element > Right click on the node in the DOM tree.
2. Select "Break on" > "node removal". Reload the page.

Name: Debug remote device pages
Description: Can I debug websites on remote devices?

Notes: 1. In the Menu bar, select **Develop** > Select the device > Select the page to open the **Web Inspector** for that URL.

Name: Debug scroll overflow
Description: Can I debug unwanted scrollbars?

Firefox.Notes: 1. In the **Inspector** panel, the elements with scrollbars have a `scroll` badge next to it. Click on the badge to jump to the element(s) that caused it.

Polypane.Notes: 1. Press `Cmd/Ctrl+D` to turn on layout debugging. Elements causing a scrollbar are marked in red.

Name: Debug subtree change
Description: Can I debug by setting a breakpoint when the subtree of the node changes?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect element > Right click on the node in the DOM tree.
2. Select "Break on" > "subtree modifications". Reload the page.

Name: Debug XHR & Fetch calls
Description: Can I debug XHR or fetch calls by setting a breakpoint for a specific or all requests??

Chrome.Notes:
1. Click the **Sources** tab.
2. Expand the **XHR Breakpoints** pane.
3. Click **Add breakpoint**.
4. Enter the string which you want to break on. DevTools pauses when this string is present anywhere in an XHR's request URL.
5. Press Enter to confirm.

Firefox.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Debugger. 
2. In the right section, under "XHR Breakpoints",  either use the checkbox to "Pause on any URL" or "Break when the URL contains" a specific keyword

Edge.Notes:
1. Click the Sources tab.
2. Expand the XHR Breakpoints pane.
3. Click Add breakpoint.
4. Enter the string which you want to break on. DevTools pauses when this string is present anywhere in an XHR's request URL.
5. Press Enter to confirm.

Safari.Notes:
1. In the **Sources** tab, click the "+" button in the left sidebar within the **Breakpoints** section > Select "URL Breakpoint..."
2. Use the popup form to apply breakpoint on specific keywords and matching conditions.
3. Alternatively, you can set breakpoint on all the requests by selecting "All Requests" after clicking the "+" button.

Opera.Notes:
1. Click the **Sources** tab.
2. Expand the **XHR Breakpoints** pane.
3. Click **Add breakpoint**.
4. Enter the string which you want to break on. DevTools pauses when this string is present anywhere in an XHR's request URL.
5. Press Enter to confirm.

Name: Delete node
Description: Can I delete a node from the DOM tree?

Notes: 1. In the **Elements** panel, right click on the node and select "Delete element".

Name: Detect memory leaks
Description: Can I detect memory leaks in my web app using devtools?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux) > Memory.
2. Check memory usage > Memory going only ⬆️ is a bad sign! > Capture snapshot to preview memory allocation > Find redundant objects > Navigate to where you allocated them.

Firefox.Notes:
1. In the **Memory** tab, use the camera icon (top-left) titled, "Take snapshot" to capture the heap stack and establish a baseline.
2. Perform any operation on the app that is suspected to leak memory, and then take another snapshot.
3. To compare two snapshots, click the button that looks like a Venn diagram next to the camera icon. The diff shows you where memory was allocated or freed between the two snapshots, indicating potential candidates leaking the memory.

Edge.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux) > Memory.
2. Check memory usage > Memory going only ⬆️ is a bad sign! > Capture snapshot to preview memory allocation > Find redundant objects > Navigate to where you allocated them.

Safari.Notes:
1. Open the **Timelines** tab. In the **Events** view, enable "JavaScript Allocations" panel in the left sidebar, by clicking the **Edit** button.
2. Reload the page to start recording the timeline. Perform actions that are expected to be memory neutral.
3. Take snapshot using the **Camera** icon after each repetition. Use the **Compare** button to compare the snapshots for any visible memory spikes.

Opera.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux) > Memory.
2. Check memory usage > Memory going only ⬆️ is a bad sign! > Capture snapshot to preview memory allocation > Find redundant objects > Navigate to where you allocated them.

Name: Disable cache
Description: Can I disable cache for the network requests?

Chrome.Notes: 1. Open Network panel > Look for "Disable cache" in the toolbar at the top.

Firefox.Notes: 1. Open Network panel > Look for "Disable Cache" in the toolbar at the top.

Edge.Notes: 1. Open Network panel > Look for "Disable Cache" in the toolbar at the top.

Safari.Notes: 1. Open Network panel > Look for the icon in the top right of the toolbar with tooltip "Ignore the resource cache when loading resources".

Opera.Notes: 1. Open Network panel > Look for "Disable cache" in the toolbar at the top.

Polypane.Notes: 1. In the Edit menu, select "Disable cache" and choose to disable it just for the current session, or persistently.

Name: Disable JavaScript
Description: Can I disable JavaScript on a web page?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open devtools. Press `Shift+Cmd+P` on Mac or `Ctrl+Shit+P` on Windows/Linux/Chrome OS to open the Command Menu.
2. Search for "Disable JavaScript" and press `Enter` to execute the command.
3. The yellow warning icon next to the Sources panel is the indicator that the JavaScript is disabled. It will continue to be disabled until the devtools is closed.

Firefox.Notes:
1. Navigate to `about:config` in the address bar. Click on "Accept the Risk and Continue" while proceeding with caution.
2. Search for "javascript.enabled" in the preference textbox.
3. Toggle the boolean value to False, using the `⇋` button.

Edge.Notes:
1. Open devtools. Press `Shift+Cmd+P` on Mac or `Ctrl+Shit+P` on Windows/Linux/Chrome OS to open the Command Menu.
2. Search for "Disable JavaScript" and press `Enter` to execute the command.
3. The yellow warning icon next to the Sources panel is the indicator that the JavaScript is disabled. It will continue to be disabled until the devtools is closed.

Safari.Notes:
1. In the menu bar, navigate to Safari > Preferences.
2. Click on the Security tab. Under the Web Content section, uncheck the "Enable JavaScript" checkbox.

Opera.Notes:
1. Open devtools. Press `Shift+Cmd+P` on Mac or `Ctrl+Shit+P` on Windows/Linux/Chrome OS to open the Command Menu.
2. Search for "Disable JavaScript" and press `Enter` to execute the command.
3. The yellow warning icon next to the Sources panel is the indicator that the JavaScript is disabled. It will continue to be disabled until the devtools is closed.

Polypane.Notes:
1. Open the "debug tools" of an individual pane.
2. under "Disable features", select "Disable JS".

Name: Display FPS on page
Description: Can I display the current frames per second (FPS) of the page?

Notes: 1. Open **Command Menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Run "Show frames per second (FPS) meter".
1. Open **Command Menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Run "Show frames per second (FPS) meter".
1. Open **Command Menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Run "Show frames per second (FPS) meter".

Name: Drag & Drop element
Description: Can I drag & drop nodes anywhere inside the DOM tree?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect element or Press `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux).
2. Select the node and drag-n-drop to a different part of the DOM tree.

Firefox.Notes:
1. Right click > Inspect element or Press `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux).
2. Select the node and drag-n-drop to a different part of the DOM tree.

Edge.Notes:
1. Right click > Inspect element or Press `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux).
2. Select the node and drag-n-drop to a different part of the DOM tree.

Safari.Notes: 1. Select any DOM node from the DOM tree, drag and drop anywhere in the tree to place the element.

Opera.Notes:
1. Right click > Inspect element or Press `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux).
2. Select the node and drag-n-drop to a different part of the DOM tree.

Name: Duplicate node
Description: Can I duplicate a node in the DOM tree?

Notes: 1. In the **Elements** panel, right click on the node and select "Duplicate element".

Name: Edit node as HTML
Description: Can I edit the node as HTML?

Notes: 1. In the **Elements** panel, right click on the node and select "Edit as HTML".

Name: Emulate blurred vision
Description: Can I emulate blurred vision on a page?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Run **Command** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > "Show Rendering" (Drawer).
2. Navigate to the **Emulate vision deficiencies** section and choose "Blurred vision".

Edge.Notes:
1. Run **Command** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > "Show Rendering" (Drawer).
2. Navigate to the **Emulate** **vision** **deficiencies** section and choose "Blurred vision".

Opera.Notes:
1. Run **Command** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > "Show Rendering" (Drawer).
2. Navigate to the **Emulate** **vision** **deficiencies** section and choose "Blurred vision".

Polypane.Notes:
1. Open the "debug tools" of an individual pane.
2. Go to the "Simulators" tab.
3. Choose between "Far-sightedness" and "Astigmatism".

Name: Emulate color schemes
Description: Can I emulate different color schemes for dark and light mode?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Inside the "Styles" pane, right next to the "+" button, click the Icon "Toggle common rendering emulations".
2. Choose the `prefers-color-scheme` option to emulate the corresponding color scheme.

Firefox.Notes: 1. Open devtools > Inspector > Next to the "Filter Styles" section, are the icons to toggle between light, dark color schemes.

Edge.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Inside the "Styles" pane, right next to the "+" button, click the Icon "Toggle common rendering emulations".
2. Choose the `prefers-color-scheme` option to emulate the corresponding color scheme.

Safari.Notes: Open **Web Inspector** using `Cmd+Opt+I`. Look for the icon in the top right of the Elements panel, to toggle between "Force Dark Appearance" and "Use Default Appearance".

Opera.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Inside the "Styles" pane, right next to the "+" button, click the Icon "Toggle common rendering emulations".
2. Choose the `prefers-color-scheme` option to emulate the corresponding color scheme.

Polypane.Notes:
1. Open the "Media and Emulation" settings of a pane.
2. Under "Media features", Toggle between light and dark values for `prefers-color-scheme`.

Name: Emulate devices
Description: Can I emulate devices to test responsiveness of a page?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on MacOS) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux).
2. Press `Cmd+Shift+M` (on MacOS) or `Ctrl+Shift+M` (on Windows/Linux) or click the devices icon in the top right to "Toggle device toolbar".

Firefox.Notes:
There are three ways to toggle Responsive Design Mode:
1. From the Firefox menu: Select **Responsive Design Mode** from the **Web Developer** submenu in the Firefox Menu (or **Tools** menu if you display the menu bar or are on macOS).
2. From the Developer Tools toolbox: Press the **Responsive Design Mode** button in the Toolbox’s toolbar.
3. From the keyboard: Press **Ctrl**+**Shift**+**M** (or **Cmd**+**Opt**+**M** on macOS).

Edge.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on MacOS) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux).
2. Press `Cmd+Shift+M` (on MacOS) or `Ctrl+Shift+M` (on Windows/Linux) or click the devices icon in the top right to "Toggle device toolbar".

Safari.Notes: 1. From the menu bar: Develop > Enter Responsive Design Mode (or press `Ctrl+Cmd+R`).

Opera.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on MacOS) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux).
2. Press `Cmd+Shift+M` (on MacOS) or `Ctrl+Shift+M` (on Windows/Linux) or click the devices icon in the top right to "Toggle device toolbar".

Polypane.Notes:
1. Click the title of a pane.
2. Select one of the 30+ available device presets
3. Optionally, switch between the _viewport size_ and _device size_. Viewport size takes the device UI into account to give you the real available space.

Name: Emulate idle detection
Description: Can I emulate detection of the user state as idle?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open **Command Menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Run "Sensors" > Press `Enter`.
2. Scroll down to the section "Emulate Idle Detector state" and select the appropriate option to force the selected idle state for emulation.

Opera.Notes:
1. Open Command Menu (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Run "Sensors" > Press `Enter`.
2. Scroll down to the section "Emulate Idle Detector state" and select the appropriate option to force the selected idle state for emulation.

Name: Emulate print styles
Description: Can I emulate print media query?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Launch devtools > Open "Command Menu" using `Cmd+Shift+P` (Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+P` (Windows, Linux, Chrome OS).
2. Search for "Show Rendering" and press Enter (this will open the Rendering panel next to the Console).
3. Scroll down to the section "Emulate CSS Media Type" and select "print".

Firefox.Notes: 1. Inspect > In the "Filter Styles" section on the right, look for the icon with the title, "Toggle print media simulation for the page".

Edge.Notes:
1. Launch devtools > Open "Command Menu" using `Cmd+Shift+P` (Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+P` (Windows, Linux, Chrome OS).
2. Search for "Show Rendering" and press Enter (this will open the Rendering panel next to the Console).
3. Scroll down to the section "Emulate CSS Media Type" and select "print".

Safari.Notes: 1. In the **Elements** panel, click the printer icon in the toolbar at the top to force the page to use the print media styles.

Opera.Notes:
1. Launch devtools > Open "Command Menu" using `Cmd+Shift+P` (Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+P` (Windows, Linux, Chrome OS).
2. Search for "Show Rendering" and press Enter (this will open the Rendering panel next to the Console).
3. Scroll down to the section "Emulate CSS Media Type" and select "print".

Notes: 1. Click **Change Media and Emulations** from the top toolbar > **Media** (tab) > Select **print** to emulate the print media styles.

Name: Expand DOM nodes recursively
Description: Can I expand DOM nodes recursively in the DOM tree?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Right click on the node in the DOM tree, select "Expand recursively". 
2. (Or) Use `Opt+Click` or `Alt+Click` on the arrow preceding the node with the keyboard.

Firefox.Notes:
1. Right click on the node in the DOM tree, select "Expand All". 
2. (Or) Use `Opt+Click` or `Alt+Click` on the arrow preceding the node with the keyboard.

Edge.Notes:
1. Right click on the node in the DOM tree, select "Expand recursively". 
2. (Or) Use `Opt+Click` or `Alt+Click` on the arrow preceding the node with the keyboard.

Safari.Notes:
1. Right click on the node in the DOM tree, select "Expand All".
2. (Or) Use `Opt+Click` or `Alt+Click` on the arrow preceding the node with the keyboard.

Opera.Notes:
1. Right click on the node in the DOM tree, select "Expand recursively". 
2. (Or) Use `Opt+Click` or `Alt+Click` on the arrow preceding the node with the keyboard.

Name: Extend DevTools UI
Description: Can I extend DevTools to customise UI?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Chrome DevTools can be extended to add new UI panels and sidebars, interact with the inspected page, get information about network requests, and more.
2. Refer the official guide to extend [Chrome DevTools](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/extensions/mv3/devtools/).

Firefox.Notes: 1. Firefox uses WebExtensions APIs to extend the browser's built-in developer tools. Follow the [link](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Add-ons/WebExtensions/Extending_the_developer_tools) to know how to develop extensions for the devtools.

Edge.Notes:
1. Edge DevTools can be extended to add new UI panels and sidebars, interact with the inspected page, get information about network requests, and more.
2. Refer the official guide to extend [Edge DevTools](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/extensions-chromium/developer-guide/devtools-extension).
Edge.References: 1. Create an extension that customizes the DevTools UI, by [Edge DevTools](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/extensions-chromium/developer-guide/devtools-extension).

Safari.Notes: 1. To create a Safari web extension, you create an Xcode project using the Safari Extension App template. The project includes the Safari web extension as a macOS or iOS app extension that users can download from the App Store and install in Safari.

Opera.Notes:
1. Opera uses Chromium DevTools which can be extended to add new UI panels and sidebars, interact with the inspected page, get information about network requests, and more.
2. Refer the official guide to extend [Chrome DevTools](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/extensions/mv3/devtools/).

Name: Filter blocked cookies requests
Description: Can I filter network requests with blocked response cookies?

Notes: 1. In the **Network** panel, enable the **Has blocked cookies** option to only show requests with blocked response cookies.

Name: Filter blocked requests
Description: Can I filter blocked network requests?

Notes: 1. In the **Network** panel, enable the **Blocked requests** option to show only blocked requests.

Name: Filter multiple resources
Description: Can I filter multiple resource types in the Network tab?

Chrome.References:
1. "Filter request by Type" by [Chrome Developers](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/devtools/network/reference/#filter-by-type) 
2. "Tips & Tricks #1" of the [Newsletter](https://www.getrevue.co/profile/CanIDevTools/issues/tips-tricks-1-1155265)
Chrome.Notes: Open devtools > Open the "Network" tab. Hold `Cmd` or `Ctrl` key while clicking on the Resource type.

Firefox.Notes: 1. In **Network** tab. Hold `Cmd` or `Ctrl` key while clicking on the Resource type.

Edge.Notes: Open devtools > Open the Network tab. Hold `Cmd` or `Ctrl` key while clicking on the Resource type.

Safari.Notes: Open devtools > Open the Network tab. Hold `Cmd` or `Ctrl` key while clicking on the Resource type.

Opera.Notes: Open devtools > Open the "Network" tab. Hold `Cmd` or `Ctrl` key while clicking on the Resource type.

Name: Filter requests by domain
Description: Can I filter network requests by domain name?

Chrome.Notes:
1. In **Network** > Enter `domain:` in the "Filter" field followed by the domain to filter the network requests on.
2. **Filter** field also suggests the list of domain names to choose from.

Firefox.Notes:
1. In **Network** > Enter `domain:` in the "Filter URLs" field followed by the domain to filter the network requests on.
2. Filter field also suggests the list of domain names to choose from.

Edge.Notes:
1. In **Network** > Enter `domain:` in the "Filter" field followed by the domain to filter the network requests on.
2. **Filter** field also suggests the list of domain names to choose from.

Opera.Notes:
1. In **Network** > Enter `domain:` in the "Filter" field followed by the domain to filter the network requests on.
2. Filter field also suggests the list of domain names to choose from.

Name: Filter requests by keyword
Description: Can I filter requests in the Network tab with a keyword?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open the **Network** tab > Use the "Filter" input field to filter network requests based on a specific keyword. 
2. Use the "Invert" checkbox to filter on requests which does not match the keyword.

Firefox.Notes:
1. In the **Network** tab, use the "Filter URLs" text field to filter the network requests for a specific keyword. 
2. Prepending a minus (`-`) negates the filter. You can combine different filters together by separating them with a space.

Edge.Notes:
1. Open the **Network** tab > Use the "Filter" input field to filter network requests based on a specific keyword. 
2. Use the "Invert" checkbox to filter on requests which does not match the keyword.

Safari.Notes: 1. In the **Network** tab, use the "Filter Full URL" input field to filter network requests for a specific keyword.

Opera.Notes:
1. Open the **Network** tab > Use the "Filter" input field to filter network requests based on a specific keyword. 
2. Use the "Invert" checkbox to filter on requests which does not match the keyword.

Name: Filter requests by properties
Description: Can I filter requests in the Network tab using specific properties?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Use the **Filter** text box to filter requests by properties, such as the domain or size of the request.
2. You can use multiple properties simultaneously by separating each property with a space. For example, `mime-type:image/gif larger-than:1K` displays all GIFs that are larger than one kilobyte. These multi-property filters are equivalent to AND operations. OR operations are currently not supported.

Firefox.Notes: 1. In the **Network** panel, use the "Filter URLs" field to filter network requests by properties such as domain, mime-type, size etc.,

Edge.Notes:
1. Use the Filter text box to filter requests by properties, such as the domain or size of the request.
2. You can use multiple properties simultaneously by separating each property with a space. For example, `mime-type:image/gif larger-than:1K` displays all GIFs that are larger than one kilobyte. These multi-property filters are equivalent to AND operations. OR operations are currently not supported.

Opera.Notes:
1. Use the Filter text box to filter requests by properties, such as the domain or size of the request.
2. You can use multiple properties simultaneously by separating each property with a space. For example, `mime-type:image/gif larger-than:1K` displays all GIFs that are larger than one kilobyte. These multi-property filters are equivalent to AND operations. OR operations are currently not supported.

Name: Filter third party requests
Description: Can I filter third party network requests?

Notes: 1. In the **Network** panel, enable the **Third-party requests** option to show only requests with origin different from page origin.

Name: Find broken links
Description: Can I find links on a page that return Error 404, 500?

Notes: 1. Open DevTools panel (`Cmd/Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Info > Outline. Select "Links" from the dropdown menu at the top.
2. Scroll through the list of links to identify broken links reporting status code with 404, 500.

Name: Find by XPath
Description: Can I find elements in the DOM tree using xpath?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open devtools using Cmd+Opt+I (on MacOS) or Ctrl+Shift+I (on Windows/Linux/ChromeOS) > Elements.
2. Press Cmd+F or Ctrl+F to open the search bar at the bottom of the Elements panel.
3. Enter XPath to find the element in the DOM node.

Firefox.Notes:
1. Open devtools using Cmd+Opt+I (on MacOS) or Ctrl+Shift+I (on Windows/Linux/ChromeOS) > Inspector.
2. Press Cmd+F or Ctrl+F to open the search bar at the top of the Inspector panel.
3. Enter the xpath to find the element in the DOM node.

Edge.Notes:
1. Open devtools using Cmd+Opt+I (on MacOS) or Ctrl+Shift+I (on Windows/Linux/ChromeOS) > Elements.
2. Press Cmd+F or Ctrl+F to open the search bar at the bottom of the Elements panel.
3. Enter XPath to find the element in the DOM node.

Safari.Notes:
1. In the **Elements** tab, use `Cmd+F` or `Ctrl+F` to open the search bar at the top of the Elements panel.
2. Enter the xpath to find the element in the DOM node.

Opera.Notes:
1. Open devtools using Cmd+Opt+I (on MacOS) or Ctrl+Shift+I (on Windows/Linux/ChromeOS) > Elements.
2. Press Cmd+F or Ctrl+F to open the search bar at the bottom of the Elements panel.
3. Enter XPath to find the element in the DOM node.

Name: Find color contrast
Description: Can I find the contrast ratio of a color?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect element > In the **Styles** pane, click the color square next to the `color` property. This will open the color panel.
2. Expand the "Contrast Ratio" section to see more details whether the color value meets the W3C recommendation.
3. Use the "reload" icon next to AA/AAA to use the suggested color to fix the low color contrast ratio.

Firefox.Notes:
1. Inspect the text element (this will open the devtools panel).
2. In the pane next to the DOM tree, look for the section where the `color` property is set for the element.
3. Click on the color circle next to the `color` property. This will open the color panel.

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect element > In the **Styles** pane, click the color square next to the `color` property. This will open the color panel.
2. Expand the "Contrast Ratio" section to see more details whether the color value meets the W3C recommendation.
3. Use the "reload" icon next to AA/AAA to use the suggested color to fix the low color contrast ratio.

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect element > In the Styles pane, click the color square next to the `color` property. This will open the color panel.
2. Expand the "Contrast Ratio" section to see more details whether the color value meets the W3C recommendation.
3. Use the "reload" icon next to AA/AAA to use the suggested color to fix the low color contrast ratio.

Polypane.Notes:
1. Inspect element > In the Navigator you can see the contrast ratio score (AA, A or an X for failing contrast). Hover it for the precise ratio or go to the A11y tab for more information.
2. To get a fix, go to the "Debug tools" of a pane, then under "Accessibility" click "Contrast checker". Suggestions will be shown in the page.

Name: Find element with CSS selector
Description: Can I find elements in the DOM tree using CSS selector?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Click the "Elements" panel > Press `Cmd+F` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+F` (on Windows/Linux/Chrome OS) to open the search bar.
2. Enter the CSS selector to search an element in the DOM tree.

Firefox.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Click the "Inspector" tab to open the DOM tree > Under the Inspector tab, locate the "Search HTML" field.
2. Enter the CSS selector to search the element in the DOM tree.

Edge.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Click the "Elements" panel > Press `Cmd+F` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+F` (on Windows/Linux/Chrome OS) to open the search bar.
2. Enter the CSS selector to search an element in the DOM tree.

Safari.Notes: 1. In the **Elements** tab, use `Cmd+F` or `Ctrl+F` to open the search box. Type the CSS selector and then press `Enter` to find elements matching the condition.

Opera.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Click the "Elements" panel > Press `Cmd+F` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+F` (on Windows/Linux/Chrome OS) to open the search bar.
2. Enter the CSS selector to search an element in the DOM tree.

Name: Find expensive CSS selectors
Description: Can I find expensive CSS selectors?

Edge.Notes:
1. In the **Performance** panel, Enable "advanced rendering instrumentation (slow)" in **Settings**.
2. Click **Record**, and perform the operation on the page that affects rendering.
3. In the recorded profile, identify a long style recalculation and select it in the waterfall view (“Main” section).
4. In the bottom tab bar, click **Selector Stats.** Sort the selectors based on Elapsed Time, Match Attempts etc., to identify expensive selectors.
Edge.References: 1. "The truth about CSS selector performance", by [Patrick Brosset](https://blogs.windows.com/msedgedev/2023/01/17/the-truth-about-css-selector-performance/)

Name: Find in files
Description: Can I find in files for a specific keyword?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open **Command Menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Run > "Show Search" (Drawer).
2. Enter the search query in the text field and press `Enter` to search across all download resources.

Firefox.Notes: 1. In the **Debugger** tab, press `Cmd+Shift+F` or `Ctrl+Shift+F` to find in files for a specific keyword.

Edge.Notes:
1. Open **Command** **Menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Run > "Show Search" (Drawer).
2. Enter the search query in the text field and press `Enter` to search across all download resources.

Safari.Notes: 1. Anywhere in the web inspector, press `Cmd+Shift+F` to find in files for a specific keyword.

Opera.Notes:
1. Open **Command** **Menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Run > "Show Search" (Drawer).
2. Enter the search query in the text field and press `Enter` to search across all download resources.

Name: Find inactive styles
Description: Can I find inactive styles applied to an element?

Notes: 1. Enable authoring hints, by opening **Settings** (`F1`) > **Experiments** > Filter on "authoring hints" > Check "Enable CSS Authoring hints..."
2. In **Elements** > Locate the authored styles in the **Styles** pane > Inactive declarations have an "i" icon, which on hover reveals a tooltip displaying more information.
1. In **Inspector** > Locate the styles in the **Rules** pane. Inactive styles will have an "i" icon next to it, which on hover will reveal more information about it.
1. Enable authoring hints, by opening **Settings** (`F1`) > **Experiments** > Filter on "authoring hints" > Check "Enable CSS Authoring hints..."
2. In **Elements** > Locate the authored styles in the **Styles** pane > Inactive declarations have an "i" icon, which on hover reveals a tooltip displaying more information.
