```
  "%cThis is green text with yellow background",
  "color:green; background:yellow"
)
```

Name: Target iframe in console
Description: Can I target iframes while debugging from the Console panel?

Notes: 1. In the **Console** panel, click the "top" menu, and select the iframe to target in the **Console**.
1. In the **Console** panel, click the "iframe context picker button" (top right) to launch a popup listing all the iframes in the document (including the main document).
2. Select the iframe to target in the Console. (Note: The button is only displayed if the page includes iframes!)
1. In the **Console** panel, click the "top" menu, and select the iframe to target in the **Console**.

Safari.Notes: 1. In the **Console** panel, select the target iframe from the "Execution context for $0" dropdown (bottom-right).

Notes: 1. In the **Console** panel, click the "top" menu, and select the iframe to target in the **Console**.

Name: Throttle CPU speed
Description: Can I throttle CPU speed to simulate slower machines?

Chrome.Notes: 1. In the **Performance** panel, open **Settings** using the gear icon and select the "CPU: No throttling" dropdown to choose "4x/6x slowdown".

Edge.Notes: 1. In the **Performance** panel, open **Settings** using the gear icon and select the "CPU: No throttling" dropdown to choose "4x/6x slowdown".

Opera.Notes: 1. In the **Performance** panel, open **Settings** using the gear icon and select the "CPU: No throttling" dropdown to choose "4x/6x slowdown".

Name: Throttle CSS animation speed
Description: Can I throttle CSS animation playback speed?

Notes: 1. Inspect the element with CSS `animation` property applied.
2. Open the **Command Menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Run "Show Animations (Drawer)".
3. Use the buttons (**100%, 25%, 10%**) to throttle the playback speed of the CSS animation live.

Name: Throttle network speed
Description: Can I throttle network speed to simulate slower network connections like 2G, 3G etc.,?

Chrome.Notes: 1. In **Network** > Click the dropdown "No Throttling" and select a value to throttle the network speed.

Firefox.Notes: 1. In Network > Click the dropdown "No Throttling" and select a value to throttle the network speed.

Edge.Notes: 1. In Network > Click the dropdown "No Throttling" and select a value to throttle the network speed.

Opera.Notes: 1. In Network > Click the dropdown "No Throttling" and select a value to throttle the network speed.

Notes: 1. Open **Change Media and Emulation** settings of a pane and go to the "Network" tab
2. Toggle the **Throttle network speed** switch to Fast 3G, Slow 3G or Offline.

Name: Toggle element state
Description: Can I toggle the element state like hover, visited, focus etc.,?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect an element > In the **Styles** pane (next to the DOM tree), click the `:hov` button next to the Filter box.
2. Use the checkboxes to force the element state to any of the listed pseudo classes to view the corresponding CSS applied.

Firefox.Notes:
1. Inspect an element > In the Styles pane (next to the DOM tree), click the `:hov` button next to the Filter box.
2. Use the checkboxes to force the element state to any of the listed pseudo classes to view the corresponding CSS applied.

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect an element > In the Styles pane (next to the DOM tree), click the `:hov` button next to the Filter box.
2. Use the checkboxes to force the element state to any of the listed pseudo classes to view the corresponding CSS applied.

Safari.Notes:
1. Inspect an element > Make sure the node is selected in the DOM Tree.
2. In the styles section (next to the DOM tree), right at the top toolbar, you'll find checkboxes for different pseudo states, which you can toggle to view the corresponding CSS.

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect an element > In the Styles pane (next to the DOM tree), click the `:hov` button next to the Filter box.
2. Use the checkboxes to force the element state to any of the listed pseudo classes to view the corresponding CSS applied.

Name: Toggle light & dark theme
Description: Can I switch to light or dark theme in devtools?

Chrome.Notes: Open **Command** **Menu** (`Cmd/Ctrl+Shift+P`) & Run > "Switch to light/dark theme" (Appearance) > Press `Enter`.

Firefox.Notes: 1. Open **Settings** (`F1`) > Under the **Themes** section, select "Dark" or "Light" to switch themes.

Edge.Notes: Open **Command** **Menu** (`Cmd/Ctrl+Shift+P`) & Run > "Switch to light/dark theme" (Appearance) > Press `Enter`.

Safari.Notes: Open **Settings** (`Cmd+,`) > General > Appearance > Select "Dark" or "Light" to change the appearance.

Opera.Notes: Open **Command** **Menu** (`Cmd/Ctrl+Shift+P`) & Run > "Switch to light/dark theme" (Appearance) > Press `Enter`.

Polypane.Notes: Press `Cmd/Ctrl+I` or select "Toggle Dark Mode" in the "View" Menu.

Name: Use Display P3 color
Description: Can I use Display P3 color format?

Safari.References: 1. "Wide Gamut Color in CSS", on Webkit [blog](https://webkit.org/blog/10042/wide-gamut-color-in-css-with-display-p3/).
Safari.Notes:
1. Right click on the color box > Select "Convert to Display-P3". This will change the color format to \`display-p3\`.
2. Click the color box to open the color swatch. The white line shows the edge of sRGB. Everything on its top right is **Display-P3** colors not available in sRGB.
3. For fallback, right click on the color box, and select "Clamp to sRGB" to convert to the closest available color in the sRGB space.

Name: Use easing editor
Description: Can I use the easing editor to edit transitions and animations?

Notes: 1. Inspect the element with CSS transition or animation applied. In the **Styles** pane, click the icon next to the timing function to open the **Easing editor** to play around with the timing functions.

1. Inspect the element with CSS transition or animation applied. In the **Styles** pane, click the icon next to the timing function to open the **Easing editor** to play around with the timing functions.

1. Inspect the element with CSS transition or animation applied. In the **Styles** pane, click the icon next to the timing function to open the **Easing editor** to play around with the timing functions.

1. Inspect the element with CSS transition or animation applied. In the **Rules** pane, click the icon next to the timing function to open the **Timing editor** to play around with the timing functions.

1. Inspect the element with CSS transition or animation applied. In the styles section, click the icon next to the timing function to open the **Cubic-bezier editor** to play around with the timing functions.

Name: View accessibility tree
Description: Can I view the accessibility tree?

Chrome.References:
1. Jecelyn Yeen on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/jecfish/status/1512088763198951431)
2. Full Accessibility Tree by [Chrome Developers](https://developer.chrome.com/blog/full-accessibility-tree/)
Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect > Open the Accessibility pane on the right (Click the >> icon to show more tabs, if hidden) > Check "Enable full-page accessibility tree" > Reload Devtools.
2. Click on the floating icon in the top right in the Elements panel which says, "Switch to Accessibility tree view".

Firefox.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Accessibility (Click >> icon to open more tabs if hidden).
2. The main section shows the accessibility tree under the Role section.

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect > Elements > Open the Accessibility pane on the right (Click the >> icon to show more tabs, if hidden) > Check "Enable full-page accessibility tree" > Reload Devtools.
2. Click on the floating icon in the top right in the Elements panel which says, "Switch to Accessibility tree view".

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect > Open the Accessibility pane on the right (Click the >> icon to show more tabs, if hidden) > Check "Enable full-page accessibility tree" > Reload Devtools.
2. Click on the floating icon in the top right in the Elements panel which says, "Switch to Accessibility tree view".

Name: View ARIA attrs
Description: Can I view ARIA attributes of an element?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect the element in the DOM tree.
2. Click on the Accessibility tab (It maybe hidden behind the "More Tabs" button). Scroll down to the section which says, "ARIA Attributes".

Firefox.Notes:
1. Right click on the element on the page and select "Inspect Accessibility Properties".
2. This will open the Accessibility tab. The ARIA attributes are available under the "Properties" panel on the right.

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect the element in the DOM tree.
2. Click on the Accessibility tab (It maybe hidden behind the "More Tabs" button). Scroll down to the section which says, "ARIA Attributes".

Safari.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Click the **Node** pane next to the DOM node.
2. Scroll down to the **Accessibility** section, expand to see all the ARA attributes for the selected node.

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect the element in the DOM tree.
2. Click on the Accessibility tab (It maybe hidden behind the "More Tabs" button). Scroll down to the section which says, "ARIA Attributes".

Polypane.Notes:
1. Inspect the element in the DOM tree.
2. Click on the "A11y" tab. All "ARIA Attributes" are listed here.

Name: View cascade layers
Description: Can I inspect CSS cascade layers?

Chrome.References:
1. "What's New In DevTools (Chrome 101)" - [Chrome Developers](https://developer.chrome.com/blog/new-in-devtools-101/#layer)
2. "CSS Cascade Layer Demo" - [Jecelyn Yeen](https://jec.fyi/demo/cascade-layer)
Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect the element that is part of the `@layer`. In the **Styles** pane, each layer and its corresponding styles are visible.
2. Clicking on the layer name will reveal the **CSS layers** section at the top which will contain the layer order, that drives the specificity.

Firefox.Notes: 1. Inspect the element that is part of the `@layer`. In the Styles pane, each layer and its corresponding styles are visible.

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect the element that is part of the `@layer`. In the **Styles** pane, each layer and its corresponding styles are visible.
2. Clicking on the layer name will reveal the **CSS layers** section at the top which will contain the layer order, that drives the specificity.

Safari.Notes: 1. Inspect the element that is part of the `@layer`. In the Styles pane, each layer and its corresponding styles are visible.

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect the element that is part of the `@layer`. In the **Styles** pane, each layer and its corresponding styles are visible.
2. Clicking on the layer name will reveal the **CSS layers** section at the top which will contain the layer order, that drives the specificity.

Polypane.Notes: 1. Inspect the element that is part of the `@layer`. In the **Styles** pane, each layer and its corresponding styles are visible.

Name: View computed styles
Description: Can I view computed styles?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Navigate to the Computed tab in the panel next to the DOM tree.
2. Click the "Show All" checkbox to see all the inherited values.

Firefox.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Navigate to the Computed tab in the panel next to the DOM tree.
2. Click the "Browser Styles" checkbox to see all the values inherited from the user agent.

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Navigate to the Computed tab in the panel next to the DOM tree.
2. Click the "Show All" checkbox to see all the inherited values.

Safari.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Navigate to the Computed tab in the panel next to the DOM tree.
2. Click the filter icon > Select "Show All" to see all the inherited values.

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Navigate to the Computed tab in the panel next to the DOM tree.
2. Click the "Show All" checkbox to see all the inherited values.

Polypane.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Navigate to the Computed tab in the panel next to the "Style" tab.
2. Click the "Show All" checkbox to see all the inherited values.

Name: View & Copy CSS changes
Description: Can I view and copy the CSS changes applied to an element?

Firefox.Notes: 1. In the **Rules** pane, apply changes to the CSS declarations, and then click on the **Changes** pane to see the diff. Click "Copy All Changes" button to copy the modified styles, with previous declaration automatically commented.

Safari.Notes: 1. In the **Styles** pane, apply changes to the CSS declarations, and then click on the **Changes** pane to see the diff.

Name: View in 3D
Description: Can I view a web page in 3D?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open **Command Menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Run > Show Layers. This will open a new tab called **Layers**.
2. For developers, it is useful to visualise a web page in three dimensions to,
    - Find out how complex a web page is
    - Spot out-of-viewport elements
    - Debug z-index stacking issues
    - Debug performance issues with composite layers

Edge.Notes:
1. In the devtools, open the **Command** Menu using, `Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P.` Search for "Show 3D View" and press `Enter`.
2. This will open the **3D View** drawer next to the **Console**. For developers, it is useful to visualise a web page in three dimensions to,
    - Find out how complex a web page is
    - Spot out-of-viewport elements
    - Debug z-index stacking issues
    - Debug performance issues with composite layers

Opera.Notes:
1. Open **Command** **Menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) > Run > Show Layers. This will open a new tab called **Layers**.
2. For developers, it is useful to visualise a web page in three dimensions to,
    - Find out how complex a web page is
    - Spot out-of-viewport elements
    - Debug z-index stacking issues
    - Debug performance issues with composite layers

Name: View styles of element
Description: Can I view the styles applied to a pseudo element?

Chrome.Notes:
1. Right click on the element and select "Inspect" (This will open the Elements panel in the devtools with selected element highlighted in the DOM tree).  
2. The CSS applied to the element is visible in the "Styles" tab, adjacent to the DOM tree.

Firefox.Notes:
1. Right click on the element and select "Inspect" (This will open the "Inspector" panel in the devtools with selected element highlighted in the DOM tree).
2. The CSS applied to the element is visible in the panel, adjacent to the DOM tree.

Edge.Notes:
1. Right click on the element and select "Inspect". (This will open the Elements panel in the devtools with selected element highlighted in the DOM tree).
2. The CSS applied to the element is visible in the "Styles" tab, adjacent to the DOM tree.

Safari.Notes:
1. Right click on the element and select "Inspect Element" (This will open the "Elements" panel in the devtools with selected element highlighted in the DOM tree).
2. The CSS applied to the element is visible in the panel, adjacent to the DOM tree.

Opera.Notes:
1. Right click on the element and select "Inspect" (This will open the Elements panel in the devtools with selected element highlighted in the DOM tree).  
2. The CSS applied to the element is visible in the "Styles" tab, adjacent to the DOM tree.

Polypane.Notes:
1. Right click on the element and select "Inspect" (This will open the Elements panel in the devtools with selected element highlighted in the DOM tree).  
2. The CSS applied to the element is visible in the "Styles" tab, below the Element Navigator.

Name: View transferred size
Description: Can I view the size of the data transferred over the network?

Chrome.Notes: 1. In the **Network** panel, the footer contains the size of the data transferred in Bytes. If a filter is applied, then it displays the size of the filtered resources followed by all the resources.

Firefox.Notes: 1. In the **Network** panel, the footer contains the size of the data transferred in Bytes. If a filter is applied, then it displays the size of the filtered resources followed by all the resources.

Edge.Notes: 1. In the **Network** panel, the footer contains the size of the data transferred in Bytes. If a filter is applied, then it displays the size of the filtered resources followed by all the resources.

Safari.Notes: 1. In the **Network** panel, the footer contains the size of the data transferred in Bytes. If a filter is applied, then it displays the size of the filtered resources.

Opera.Notes: 1. In the **Network** panel, the footer contains the size of the data transferred in Bytes. If a filter is applied, then it displays the size of the filtered resources followed by all the resources.

Name: Zoom In & Out Devtools
Description: Can I zoom in and out of the devtools panel?

Chrome.Notes:
1. In **Developer Tools** > Open **Command Menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) and Run > "Zoom in" or `Cmd+` or `Ctrl+` to increase the zoom level.
2. Run > "Zoom out" or `Cmd-` or `Ctrl-` to decrease the zoom level.
3. Run > "Reset zoom level" or `Cmd+0` or `Ctrl+0` to reset the zoom level.

Firefox.Notes: 1. In **Web Developer Tools** > Use `Cmd+` or `Ctrl+` to increase the zoom level. Use `Cmd-` or `Ctrl-` to decrease the zoom level. To reset the zoom level, press `Ctrl+0` or `Cmd+0`.

Edge.Notes:
1. In **Developer** **Tools** > Open **Command** **Menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) and Run > "Zoom in" or `Cmd+` or `Ctrl+` to increase the zoom level.
2. Run > "Zoom out" or `Cmd-` or `Ctrl-` to decrease the zoom level.
3. Run > "Reset zoom level" or `Cmd+0` or `Ctrl+0` to reset the zoom level.

Safari.Notes:
1. In **Web Inspector** > Use `Cmd+` or `Ctrl+` to increase the zoom level. Use `Cmd-` or `Ctrl-` to decrease the zoom level. To reset the zoom level, press `Ctrl+0` or `Cmd+0`.
2. (Or) **Settings** (`Cmd,`) > General > Zoom.

Opera.Notes:
1. In **Developer** **Tools** > Open **Command** **Menu** (`Cmd+Shift+P` or `Ctrl+Shift+P`) and Run > "Zoom in" or `Cmd+` or `Ctrl+` to increase the zoom level.
2. Run > "Zoom out" or `Cmd-` or `Ctrl-` to decrease the zoom level.
3. Run > "Reset zoom level" or `Cmd+0` or `Ctrl+0` to reset the zoom level.
